sections.title: Geometric structures on solutions of  equations of adiabatic gas motion
sections.abstract:
%
In this paper we show that characteristic covectors of equations of $n$-dimensional adiabatic gas motion, $n=1,2,3$, generate a geometric structure on every their solution.
This structure consists of a hyperplane and a non degenerate cone in each cotangent space to a solution so that the hyperplane and the cone intersect only at the zero point.
We investigate differential invariants of this structure. In particular, we find a natural linear connection on every solution.
A torsion tensor of this connection is trivial for $n=1$. For $n=2,3$, this tensor is not trivial in general.
For $n=1$, we calculate solutions having the linear connection with zero curvature tensor. For $n=2,3$, we calculate solutions with zero torsion tensor.%
sections.author: Valeriy\,Yumaguzhin
sections.keywords: Equations of adiabatic  gas motion, explicit solution, jet-bundle,  geometric structure, differential invariant, Spencer $\delta$-cohomology, linear connection, torsion tensor, curvature tensor
sections.introduction:
%
In this paper we investigate some geometric structures naturally defined on solutions of a system of equations of $n$-dimensional adiabatic gas motion, $n=1,2,3$. We apply these structures to find explicit solutions of the system.
Let $M$ be a graph of an arbitrary solution of the system and let $T_m^*M$ be a cotangent space to $M$ at a point $m\in M$.
In this paper we show that characteristic covectors of the system  generate a hyperplane $\Pl_m$ and a non degenerate cone $\Cn_m$ in every cotangent space $T_m^*M$ such that $\Pl_m\cap\Cn_m=\{0\}$.
Further, we show that the field of these hyperplanes and  cones on $M$$
   S: m \longmapsto(\Pl_m, \Cn_m), \;\; m\in M,
$
can be considered as a section of some natural bundle over $M$. This means (see, for example, \cite{Krllv}) that $S$ is a geometric structure on $M$.
We find some zero-order differential invariants of this structure: a conformal  structure, a vector field, and a Lorentzian metric.
Following the approach proposed in \cite{Yum1} and \cite{Yum2},
we construct differential invariants of first order $\T_S$ for the structure $S$. It is  a tensor of type $(1,2)$ on $M$.

The tensor $\T$ is trivial for $n=1$ and it is nontrivial in general for $n=2,3$.

Further, we construct the next first order differential invariant of $S$ which is a linear connection on $M$ such that $\T$ is its torsion tensor.
Finally, for the case $n=1$ we find explicit solutions \eqref{Sol1} possessing the linear connection with zero curvature tensor;
%
for the case of polytropic gas motion and $n=2,3$, we find classes of explicit solutions \eqref{Sol2},  \eqref{Sol31}, \eqref{Sol32}, and \eqref{Sol33} possessing the linear connection with zero torsion tensor.

%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
main_part:
%
We remind here necessary notions concerning jet-bundles, differential operators, their symbols, and geometric structures.  Details can be found in \cite{KrsLchVng}, \cite{KrsVng}, and \cite{Krllv}.

%===================================================\subsection{Jet bundles}\label{JtBndl}%
Let $M$ be an $n$-dimensional manifold, $\pi:E(\pi)\to M$ a vector bundle, $\pi_x$ the fiber of $\pi$ at point $x\in M$, and $\Gamma(\pi)$ the $C^{\infty}(M)$-module of sections of $\pi$.  By $[s]_x^k$ we denote $k$-jet of section $s\in\Gamma(\pi)$ at the point $x\in M$, by $\pi_k:J^k\pi\to M$ denote the bundles
of $k$-jets of sections of $\pi$, and by $\pi_{k,l}:J^k\pi\to J^l\pi$, $k\geq l$, denote the natural projections defined by reductions of $k$-jet to $l$-jet.

Any section $s\in \Gamma(\pi)$ defines its $k$-prolongation $j_k(s)\in\Gamma(\pi_k)$ by the formula
$
  j_k(s)(x)=[s]_x^k.
$
Let $L_s^{(k)}\subset J^k\pi$ be the image of section $j_k(s)$. Then the tangent space to $L_s^{(k)}$ at point $[s]_x^k$ is identified with the $(k+1)$-jet $[s]_x^{k+1}$. By this reason we denote this space as $\K_{[s]_x^{k+1}}$. Thus,
$
   \K_{[s]_x^{k+1}}\equiv[s]_x^{k+1}.
$
By $F_{s_k}$ we denote the fiber of $\pi_{k+1,k}$ over $s_k\in J^k\pi$,
$
 F_{s_k}=(\pi_{k+1,k})^{-1}(s_k).
$%====================================================\subsection{Differential operators}%
Suppose that $\pi$ and $\pi'$ are vector bundles over $M$. Then a  map
$
 \Delta: \Gamma(\pi)\longrightarrow\Gamma(\pi')
$
is said to be a {\it $k$-order differential operator} if there is a bundle morphism  $f_{\Delta}:J^k\pi\to E(\pi')$ such that
$
   \Delta(s)(x)=f_{\Delta}( [s]_x^k)
$
for any section $s\in\Gamma(\pi)$ and any point $x$ from its domain.

%====================================================\subsection{Symbols of differential operators}%
Let $\Delta:\Gamma(\pi)\to\Gamma(\pi')$ be a $k$-order differential operator, $k\geq 1$, $s_k\in J^k\pi$, $s_{k-1}=\pi_{k,k-1}(s_k)$, and $x=\pi_k(s_k)$. Then  a {\it symbol $\sigma(\Delta)_{s_k}$ of the operator $\Delta$ at the point $s_k$} is the restriction of the differential $df_{\Delta}$ to the tangent space $T_{s_k}F_{s_{k-1}}$ to $F_{s_{k-1}}$ at point $s_k$(see, for example, \cite{KrsLchVng}):
$$
 \sigma(\Delta)_{s_k}=df_{\Delta}\bigl|_{T_{s_k}F_{s_{k-1}}}:
T_{s_k}F_{s_{k-1}}\longrightarrow T_{f_{\Delta}(s_k)}\pi'_x.
$$
Taking into account that $F_{s_{k-1}}$ is an affine space and $\pi'_x$ is a vector space, we have the natural identification:
$
   T_{s_k}F_{s_{k-1}}\equiv F_{s_{k-1}}\quad\text{and}\quad T_{f_{\Delta}(s_k)}\pi'_x\equiv \pi'_x.
$
Further, there is the natural identification
$
  i: S^k(T_x^*M)\otimes\pi_x\equiv F_{s_{k-1}},
$
which is defined by the formula
$$
 i\bigl(df_1\odot\ldots\odot df_k\otimes s(x)\bigr)=[f_1\cdot\ldots\cdot f_k\cdot s]_x^k+s_k,
$$
where $f_1,\ldots,f_k\in C^{\infty}(M)$, $f_1(x)=\ldots =f_k(x)=0$, and $s\in\Gamma(\pi)$.

Thus the symbol  $\sigma(\Delta)_{s_k}$ is the linear map
$
 \sigma(\Delta)_{s_k}:S^k(T_x^*M)\otimes\pi_x\longrightarrow\pi'_x.
$
Let $\xi_x\in T_x^*M$ and $\xi_x^k=\xi_x\odot\ldots\odot \xi_x\in S^k(T_x^*M)$. Then the symbol $\sigma(\Delta)_{s_k}$ generates the linear map
$
 \sigma_{\xi_x}(\Delta)_{s_k}:\pi_x\longrightarrow\pi'_x
$
by the formula
$$
 \sigma_{\xi_x}(\Delta)_{s_k}(w_x)=\frac{1}{k!}\sigma(\Delta)_{s_k}(\xi_x^k\otimes w_x).
$$
We shall say that this map $\sigma_{\xi_x}(\Delta)_{s_k}$ is the {\it value of the symbol $\sigma(\Delta)_{s_k}$ at the covector $\xi_x$}.

%---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsubsection{Coordinates}%
Suppose $\pi$ and $\pi'$ are vector bundles over $M$ of dimensions $m$ and $m'$ respectively and  $\Delta: \Gamma(\pi)\to\Gamma(\pi')$ is a quasilinear $k$-order differential operator.
Then we have in local coordinates
$$
  \Delta(s)=\Bigl(A_{ \alpha,i}^{i'}(j_{k-1}s)\frac{\partial^ks^i}{(\partial x^1)^{ \alpha_1}\ldots(\partial x^n)^{ \alpha_n}}+B^{i'}(j_{k-1}s)\Bigr),
$$
where $s=(s^1,\ldots,s^m)\in \Gamma(\pi)$, $\alpha=( \alpha_1,\ldots,\alpha_n)$ and $ \alpha_1+\cdots+\alpha_n=k$. The value of the symbol $\sigma(\Delta)_{s_k}$ at covector $\xi_x=\xi_idx^i$ is defined by the formula
$$
   \sigma_{\xi_x}(\Delta)_{s_k}( w_x)=\frac{1}{k!}\Bigl(A_{\alpha,i}^{i'}(s_{k-1})\xi^{\alpha} w_x^i\Bigr),
$$
where $\xi^{ \alpha}=\xi_1^{ \alpha_1}\ldots \xi_n^{ \alpha_n}$ and  $ w_x=( w_x^1,\ldots, w_x^m)\in\pi_x$.

%====================================================\subsection{Geometric structures and differential invariants}%
We denote by $\Dif$ the pseudogroup of local diffeomorphisms of $M$.

The bundle $\pi:E(\pi)\to M$ is called {\it natural}, if for every $\varphi\in\Dif$, there is a diffeomorphism $\varphi^{(0)}:E(\pi)\to E(\pi)$ such that the following conditions hold:
\begin{enumerate}
  \item  $\pi\circ \varphi^{(0)}=\varphi\circ\pi$,
  \item   $(\varphi_1\circ \varphi_2)^{(0)}=\varphi_1^{(0)}\circ \varphi_2^{(0)}$,\;\;$\forall\,\varphi_1,\,\varphi_2\in\Dif$,
  \item  $\id_M^{(0)}=\id_{E(\pi)}$.
\end{enumerate}
It follows from these conditions that $\varphi^{(0)}$ is defined uniquely.
%
The diffeomorphism $\varphi^{(0)}$ is said to be the {\it lifting of diffeomorphism $\varphi$}.
Examples of natural bundles are tangent and cotangent bundles, any tensor bundle and etc.
A section of natural bundle over $M$ is called a {\it geometric structure on $M$}(see, for example, \cite{Krllv}).

Let $\pi$ be a natural bundle. Then it is defined the natural action of $\Dif$ on geometric structures $s\in\Gamma(\pi)$$$
 \Dif\times\Gamma(\pi)\longrightarrow\Gamma(\pi), \quad (\varphi,s)\mapsto \varphi\!\cdot\! s=\varphi^{(0)}\!\circ\! s\!\circ\!\varphi^{-1}.
$$
This action generates the lifting of every $\varphi\in \Dif$ to the diffeomorphism $\varphi^{(k)}$ of total space $J^k(\pi)$ by the formula
$$
   \varphi^{(k)}(\,[s]_a^k\,)=\bigl[\varphi^{(0)}\!\circ\! s\!\circ\!\varphi^{-1}\bigl]_{f(a)}^k,\quad[s]_a^k\in J^k\pi.
$$
As a result, the bundle $\pi_k$ with this lifting is a natural bundle.
It is clear that
$$
  \pi_{k,l}\circ\varphi^{(k)}=\varphi^{(l)}\circ\pi_{k,l}\quad\forall\,\varphi\in \Dif.
$$
Let $X$ be a vector field in $M$ and let $\varphi_t$ be its flow. Then the flow $\varphi^{(k)}_t$ in  $J^k\pi$ generates lifted vector field $X^{(k)}$ in $J^k\pi$.
Obviously,
$$
   (\pi_k)_*(X^{(k)})=X\;\;\text{and}\;\;
   (\pi_{k,l})_*(X^{(k)})=X^{(l)},\;\;k\geq l.
$$
The pseudogroup $\Dif$ acts on every jet bundle $J^k\pi$ by its lifted diffeomorphisms.

Any geometric structure defined on $J^k\pi$ and invariant with respect to the action of $\Dif$ on $J^k\pi$ is called a {\it differential invariant of order $k$  of the bundle $\pi$}.
In particular, a function on $J^k\pi$ constant on the orbits of the action of $\Dif$ is called a {\it scalar  differential invariant of order $k$ of $\pi$}.

Let $\Psi$ be a differential invariant of order $k$ of $\pi$ and let $s\in\Gamma(\pi)$. Then the restriction of  $\Psi$ on image $\im j_k(s)$ of section $j_k(s)$ is called the {\it value of $\Psi$ on the section $s$} or {\it differential invariant of order $k$ of geometric structure $s$} and is denoted by $\Psi_s$,
\begin{equation}\label{InvGmtrStr}
   \Psi_s=\Psi\circ j_k(s).
\end{equation}%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

%\subsection{Equations of adiabatic gas motion}%
The system of equations of adiabatic gas motion in the space $\R^n$, $n=1,2,3$, relating components of a velocity $(v^1, \ldots, v^n)$, a density $\rho$, and a pressure $p$ as functions of a point $(x^1, \ldots, x^n)\in\R^n$ and a time $t$ is  the following system of first order quasilinear PDEs (see, for example, \cite{Ovs}):
\begin{equation}\label{Gas}
\left\{
\begin{aligned}
  &v^i_t+v^1v^i_{x^1}+\cdots +v^nv^i_{x^n}+p_{x^i}/\rho=0,\; i=1,\ldots,n,\\
  &\rho_t+v^1\rho_{x^1}+\cdots+v^n\rho_{x^n}+\rho(v^1_{x^1}
+\cdots +v^n_{x^n})=0,\\
&p_t+v^1p_{x^1}+\cdots+v^np_{x^n}+A(\rho,p)(v^1_{x^1}+\cdots +v^n_{x^n})=0.
 \end{aligned}\right.
\end{equation}
where $A(\rho,p)$ is a function depending only on $\rho$ and $p$ and
$
  A(\rho,p)>0
$ for all $\rho$ and $p$.
Consider the trivial bundle
$$
 \pi:E(\pi)=\R^{n+1}\times\R^{n+2}\longrightarrow\R^{n+1},\quad\pi:(x,\;u)\mapsto x,
$$
where $x=(x^0, x^1, \ldots, x^n)=(t, x^1, \ldots, x^n)$ and $u=(u^1,\ldots, u^{n+2})=(v^1,\ldots$, $v^n, \rho, p)$.
By $x^j, u^i, u^i_{j_1},\ldots, u^i_{j_1\ldots j_k}$ denote coordinates on the jet bundle $J^k\pi$, $k=0,1,2,\ldots$ generated by the standard coordinates $x^j, u^i$ on $E(\pi)$.

Equations \eqref{Gas} defines the submanifold $\E\subset J^1\pi$. We identify $\E$ with system \eqref{Gas} and call it as the {\it equation of adiabatic gas motion}.
A section $s\in\Gamma(\pi)$  is a solution of system \eqref{Gas}(the equation $\E$), if and only if  $L_s^{(1)}\subset\E$. We identify $s$ with its image $L_s^{(0)}$.
It follows from equations \eqref{Gas} that
$
  \pi_{1,0}(\E)=E(\pi).
$%====================================================\subsection{Symbols of PDE system ({\bf\ref{Gas}})}%
Let $s\in\Gamma(\pi)$. Then it is defined in the coordinates $x,u$ by the formula
$
   s(x)=\bigl(u^1(x),\ldots,u^{n+2}(x)\bigr).
$
Denote by $\Phi^1,\ldots,\Phi^{n+2}$ left parts of equations \eqref{Gas} respectively. Then the differential operator
$
  \Delta:\Gamma(\pi)\longrightarrow\Gamma(\pi)
$
associated in natural way with system \eqref{Gas} is defined by the formula
$$
  \Delta(s)=\begin{pmatrix}\Phi^1\bigl(j_1(s)\bigr)\quad\\\cdots\\
  \Phi^{n+2}\bigl(j_1(s)\bigr)\end{pmatrix}.
$$
From \eqref{Gas}, we see that $\Delta$ is a first order quasilinear differential operator.

Let $s_1\in\E$, $x=\pi_1(s_1)$, let $T_x^*$ be a cotangent space to the  base $\R^{n+1}$ of $\pi$ at point $x$, and let $\xi\in T_x^*$. Then the value of symbol of operator $\Delta$ at covector $\xi$, $\sigma_{\xi}(\Delta)_{s_1}:\pi_x\to\pi_x$,
is defined by the formula
\begin{equation}\label{Smbl}
  \sigma_{\xi}(\Delta)_{s_1}(w)
=\Bigl(\,\frac{\partial \Phi^i}{\partial u^j_k}(s_0)\,\xi_k\,w^j\,\Bigr),
\end{equation}
where $w=(w^1, \ldots, w^{n+2})\in\pi_x$, $s_0=\pi_{1,0}(s_1)$, and $\xi=\xi_0dx^0+\cdots+\xi_ndx^n$.
Note that quasi-linearity of the operator $\Delta$ implies that $\sigma_{\xi}(\Delta)_{s_1}$ are independent of choice $s_1\in F_{s_0}$.

%====================================================\subsection{Characteristic varieties}%
Let $s_1\in\E$, $x=\pi_1(s_1)$, and $s_0=\pi_{1,0}(s_1)$. Remind (see \cite{KrsLchVng}) that a nonzero covector  $\xi\in T_x^*$ is {\it characteristic for the equation $\E$ at the point $s_1$} if the linear map $\sigma_{\xi}(\Delta)_{s_0}$ is degenerate.

We see from \eqref{Smbl} that a covector  $\xi\in T_x^*$ is characteristic for the equation $\E$ at the point $s_1$ if and only if
$
   \det\Bigl(\,\frac{\partial\Phi^i}{\partial u^j_k}(s_0)\,\xi_k\,\Bigr)=0.
$
Rewriting the last equation in detail, we get the following one
\begin{multline}\label{ChrctVrt}
   (\xi_0+u^1\xi_1+\cdots+u^n\xi_n)^n
          \times\bigl(\;(\xi_0+u^1\xi_1+\cdots+u^n\xi_n)^2
           -\frac{A}{u^{n+1}}(\xi_1^2+\cdots+\xi_n^2)\;\bigr)=0
\end{multline}
where $u^1,\ldots,u^{n+2}$ are fiber coordinates of the point $s_0$.

The set of all characteristic covectors at the point $s_1$ is called the {\it characteristic variety of $\E$ at point $s_1$}.
We see from \eqref{ChrctVrt} that the characteristic variety at $s_1$
consists of  union of the hyperplane $P_{s_0}\subset T_x^*$ and  the non degenerate cone $C_{s_0}\subset T_x^*$ defined by equations
\begin{equation}\label{Pl}
  \xi_0+u^1\xi_1+\cdots+u^n\xi_n=0
\end{equation}
and
\begin{equation}\label{Cn}
  (\xi_0+u^1\xi_1+\cdots+u^n\xi_n)^2
           -\frac{A}{u^{n+1}}(\xi_1^2+\cdots+\xi_n^2)=0
\end{equation}
respectively.
In addition, we see that
\begin{equation}\label{PlIntrsctCn}
  P_{s_0}\cap C_{s_0}=\{0\}.
\end{equation}
Note that for $n=1$ the non degenerate cone $C_{s_0}$ is the pair of different 1-dimensional subspaces of $T_x^*$ defined  respectively by the equations
$$%\begin{align*}
  \xi_0+\bigl(\,u^1+\sqrt{A/u^2}\,\bigr)\,\xi_1=0,\quad \xi_0+\bigl(\,u^1- \sqrt{A/u^2}\,\bigr)\,\xi_1=0.
$$%\end{align*}
Thus for $n=1$, the characteristic variety at $s_1$ consists of the union of three 1-dimensional subspace of $T_x^*$ such that any two of them are transversal.

%====================================================\subsection{Geometric structures on solutions}%
Let $s$ be an arbitrary solution of the equation $\E$, $M=L_s^{(0)}$ the image of $s$, and $T_m^*M$ the cotangent space to $M$ at a point $m\in M$.  Then $s$ generates the field of hyperplanes and cones on $M$\begin{equation}\label{StrPlnCn}
 S: m\longmapsto (\Pl_m, \Cn_m),\;\; m\in M,
\end{equation}
where $\Pl_m=(\pi|_M)^*(P_m)\subset T_m^*M$, $\Cn_m=(\pi|_M)^*(C_m)\subset T_m^*M$, and $\pi|_M$ is the restriction of $\pi$ to $M$, in addition,
$
  \Pl_m\cap \Cn_m=\{0\}.
$
Show that $S$ is a geometric structure on $M$.

Let $\Pl'_m$ be an arbitrary hyperplane in $T_m^*M$, $\Cn'_m$ an arbitrary non degenerate cone in $T_m^*M$, and $\Pl'_m\cap\Cn'_m=\{0\}$.
Then $\Pl'_m$ and $\Cn'_m$ are defined respectively by the equations
$
   a^i\xi_i=0$ and $ g^{ij}\xi_i\xi_j=0,$
where collection of coefficients $(a^0,\ldots,a^n)$ and symmetric matrix $(g^{ij})$ are defined up to nonzero factors, in addition
\begin{equation}\label{Cndtns0}
\det(g^{ij})\neq 0,\;\;\text{and}\;\; g^{ij}\xi_i\xi_j\neq 0,\;\;\forall\,
(\xi_0,\ldots,\xi_n)\in\Pl'_m.
\end{equation}
This means that the pair $(\Pl'_m, \Cn'_m)$ is identified with the point
\begin{multline*}
 \bigl(m,\,[a^0:\ldots:a^n],[g^{00}:2g^{01}:\ldots:2g^{0n}\\
:\ldots:g^{n-1\, n-1}:2g^{n-1\,n}:g^{nn}]\bigr)\in m\times
\bigl(\RP^n\times\RP^{\frac{(n+1)(n+2)}{2}-1}\bigr),
\end{multline*}
where $\RP^l$ is the $l$-dimensional projective space associated with $(l+1)$-dimensi\-onal arithmetic space $\R^{l+1}$.
Conditions \eqref{Cndtns0} define the open subset $B\subset \RP^n\times\RP^{\frac{(n+1)(n+2)}{2}-1}$.

Denote by $\lambda_m$ the set of all pairs $(\Pl'_m, \Cn'_m)$, $\Pl'_m\cap\Cn'_m=\{0\}$, in the space $T_m^*M$.
%
Clearly that $\lambda_m$ is identified with the set $m\times B$.
Consider the trivial bundle
$$
  \lambda:E(\lambda)=\bigcup_{m\in M}\lambda_m=M\times B\longrightarrow M.
$$
Let $f$ be a diffeomorphism of $M$. Then, considering points of $E(\lambda)$ as corresponding pairs $(\Pl'_m,\Cn'_m)$, we can lift $f$ to the diffeomorphism $f^{(0)}$ of $E(\lambda)$ by the formula
\begin{equation}\label{Lftng}
   f^{(0)}\bigl((\Pl'_m,\Cn'_m)\bigr)=\Bigl(\bigl((f^{-1})^*(\Pl'_m)\bigr)_{f(m)},\bigl((f^{-1})^*(\Cn'_m)\bigr)_{f(m)}\Bigr).
\end{equation}
The bundle $\lambda$ with this lifting of diffeomorphisms of $M$ is a natural bundle.
We will call this natural bundle as the {\it bundle of hyperplanes and cones}.

Thus we proved the following statement.
\begin{proposition}
  The field $S:m\mapsto(\Pl_m, \Cn_m),\; m\in M$, is a geometric structure on $M$.
\end{proposition}
Remark that for $n=1$ the geometric structure $S$ is a 3-web on $M$.

The expression of structure $S$ in coordinates as a section of $\lambda$ is the following.
%\begin{multline}\label{GmtrcStrctr1}
 S:x\longmapsto \Bigl(\bigl[1:u^1(x):\ldots:u^n(x)\bigr],\;\bigl[1:2u^1(x):\ldots:2u^n(x)\\
:u^1(x)^2-A/u^{n+1}(x):\ldots :2u^1(x)u^n(x)\\
\ldots \\
:u^n(x)^2-A/u^{n+1}(x)\bigr]\Bigr).
\end{multline}%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

\label{ZrOrdrDffInv}
 In this section we construct some differential invariants of zero order of the geometric structures $S:m\longmapsto(\Pl_m, \Cn_m)$, $m\in M$, generated by solution $s=(u^1,\ldots, u^{n+2})$ of system \eqref{Gas}.

Clearly that the field of planes
$
   \Pl:m\longmapsto\Pl_m,\;\; m\in M
$
is a differential invariant of $0$-order of the structure $S$.
From \eqref{Pl} we see that this field is generated by the natural 1-dimensio\-nal distribution spanned by the vector field
\begin{equation}\label{NtrVctFld}
  V=\frac{\partial}{\partial x^0}+u^1\frac{\partial}{\partial x^1}+\cdots
       +u^n\frac{\partial}{\partial x^n}
\end{equation}
on $M$.
This distribution $\langle\, V\,\rangle$ is a differential invariant of $0$-order of $S$.

The field of non degenerate cones
$
   \Cn:m\longmapsto\Cn_m,\;\; m\in M
$
is also a differential invariant of $0$-order of the structure $S$.
This field is defined by equation \eqref{Cn}. Coefficients of this equation are defined up to multiplication on the same a nonzero function.
This means that the left side of  equation \eqref{Cn} defines conformal metric
$$
  g^{-1}(\xi,\xi)=\bigl(\xi_0+u^1\xi_1+\cdots+u^n\xi_n\bigr)^2
  -\frac{A}{u^{n+1}}(\xi_1^2+\cdots+\xi_n^2),
$$
where $\xi=(\xi_0,\xi_1,\ldots,\xi_n)\in T_m^*(M)$.
One can obtain by direct calculations that the dual conformal metric $g$ is defined by the formula
 \begin{multline}\label{CnfrmlMtrc}
 g=\frac{u^{n+1}}{A}\Bigl(\bigl(\,\frac{A}{u^{n+1}}-(u^1)^2-\cdots-(u^n)^2\;\bigr)(dx^0)^2 -(dx^1)^2-\cdots-(dx^n)^2+\\
+2u^1dx^0dx^1+\cdots+2u^ndx^0dx^n\Bigr).
\end{multline}
These conformal metrics have signature (1,3) and they are differential invariants of $0$-order of the structure $S$.

%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

%
In this section we use the approach presented in \cite{Yum1}, \cite{Yum2} to construct first order differential invariants of the structure $S$.

%====================================================\subsection{Coordinate expression of lifted vector fields}%
Let $X$ be a vector field in the base $M$ of  the natural bundle of hyperplanes and cones $\lambda$. We describe here the lifted vector field  $X^{(0)}$ in local coordinates of the total space $E(\lambda)$.

We will use the following coordinates. The coordinates $x^0$, $x^1$, $\ldots$, $x^n$ on the base $M$; the standard local coordinates $a^1$, $\ldots $, $a^n$;\;$2g^{01}$, $\ldots$, $2g^{0n}$, $\ldots$, $g^{n-1\,n-1}$, $2g^{n-1\,n}$, $g^{nn}$ on the fiber $\RP^n\times\RP^{\frac{(n+1)(n+2)}{2}-1}$ defined by affine hyperplanes $a^0=1$ and $g^{00}=1$ in $\R^{n+1}$ and $\R^{\frac{(n+1)(n+2)}{2}}$ respectively.

Let $f$ be a diffeomorphism of $M$. If $f$ is not very different from the identity map, then its lifting $f^{(0)}$ is defined in the local coordinates by the formula
$
f^{(0)}(x,a,g)=(\tilde x,\tilde a,\tilde g),
$
where
\begin{equation}\label{f0}
 \begin{aligned}
  &\tilde x=f(x)\,,\quad\tilde a^i=\frac{f^i_k(x)a^k}{f^0_k(x)a^k},\quad a^0=1,\\
  &\tilde g^{ij}=\frac{f^i_k(x)f^j_l(x)g^{kl}}{f^0_k(x)f^0_l(x)g^{kl}},\quad g^{kl}=g^{kl},\quad g^{00}=1\,,
 \end{aligned}
\end{equation}
here $f=(f^0,f^1,\ldots,f^n)$ and $f^l_k=\partial f^l/\partial x^k$.
Let
$$
 X=X^0\frac{\partial}{\partial x^0}+X^1\frac{\partial}{\partial x^1}+\cdots
 +X^n\frac{\partial}{\partial x^n}.
$$
Then we get from \eqref{f0} that
\begin{multline}\label{X0}
  X^{(0)}=X^i\frac{\partial}{\partial x^i}
  +(a^j X^i_j-a^ia^j X^0_j)\frac{\partial}{\partial a^i}
  +(g^{kj} X^i_k+g^{ki} X^j_k-2g^{ij}g^{k0} X^0_k)\frac{\partial}{\partial g^{ij}},
\end{multline}
where $X^i_j=\partial X^i/\partial x^j$.

%====================================================\subsection{Spaces ${\bf \A_{\theta_1}}$}%
Let $m\in M$, $\theta_0=S(m)$, and $\theta_1=[S]_m^1$.
Remind, see subsection~\ref{JtBndl}, that the jet $\theta_1$ is naturally identified with the tangent space $\K_{\theta_1}$ to image of section $S$ at point $\theta_0$.

Let $X$ be a vector field in $M$ defined in a neighborhood of $m$. Then  its lifting $X^{(0)}$ is a vector field in $E(\lambda)$ defined  in a neighborhood of $\theta_0$.
The value $X^{(0)}_{\theta_0}$ of $X^{(0)}$ at $\theta_0$ is defined by the 1-jet $[X]_m^1$ of $X$ at point  $m=\lambda(\theta_0)$.
Consider vector fields $X$ in $M$ defined in neighborhoods of $m$.
Introduce the following vector space of 1-jets at $m$ of these vector fields:
$
  \A_{\theta_1}=\{\,[X]_m^1\,|\,X^{(0)}_{\theta_0}\in \K_{\theta_1}\,\}\,.
$
Let's describe this space in local coordinates.
The local coordinates $x^i$, $a^j$, $g^{kl}$ of the total space $E(\lambda)$ introduced in the previous subsection
generate a local coordinates $x^i$, $a^j$, $g^{kl}$, $a^j_r$, $g^{kl}_r$ of the bundle $J^1\lambda$.
Let $\theta_1=(\,\bar x^i,\; \bar a^j,\; \bar g^{kl},\;\bar a^j_r,\; \bar g^{kl}_r\,)$
in these coordinates. Then the space $\K_{\theta_1}$ is spanned by vectors
$ D_i^1=\partial/\partial x^i+\bar a^j_i\partial/\partial a^j+\bar g^{kl}_i\partial/\partial g^{kl}$, $i=0,1,\ldots,n$, of  the tangent space to $E(\lambda)$ at $\theta_0$,
$
  \K_{\theta_1}=\langle\,D_0^1,\,D_1^1,\ldots,D_n^1\,\rangle.
$
Let $X$ be a vector field in $M$ defined in a neighborhood of $m$ and let $[X]_m^1=(\bar x, \bar X^i, \bar X^i_j)$. Then taking into account \eqref{X0}, we can represent a vector $X^{(0)}_{\theta_0}$ in the following way
\begin{multline*}
  \bar X^{(0)}_{\theta_0}=\bar X^iD_i^1 %\\
  +(\bar a^j \bar X^i_j-\bar a^i\bar a^j \bar X^0_j-\bar X^j\bar a^i_j)\frac{\partial}{\partial a^i}%\\
  +(\bar g^{kj} \bar X^i_k+\bar g^{ki} \bar X^j_k-2\bar g^{ij}\bar g^{k0} \bar X^0_k-\bar X^k\bar g^{ij}_k)\frac{\partial}{\partial g^{ij}}.
\end{multline*}
The next statement follows directly from this representation.
\begin{proposition}\label{Atht1}
Let $X$ be a vector field in $M$ defined in a neighborhood of $m$. Then  $[X]_m^1=(\bar x, \bar X^i, \bar X^i_j)\in\A_{\theta_1}$ if and only if  the vector $(\bar X^i, \bar X^i_j)$ is a solution of the system of linear algebraic equations
\begin{equation}\label{Atht2}
 \begin{aligned}
  &\bar a^j X^i_j-\bar a^i\bar a^j X^0_j-X^j\bar a^i_j=0,\quad \bar g^{kj} X^i_k+\bar g^{ki} X^j_k-2\bar g^{ij}\bar g^{k0} X^0_k-X^k\bar
    g^{ij}_k=0.
 \end{aligned}
\end{equation}
\end{proposition}%======================================================\subsection{Isotropy algebras}%
We denote by $\g_{\theta_0}$ the subspace of $\A_{\theta_1}$ defined by the formula
$
\g_{\theta_0}=\{\,[X]_m^1\in\A_{\theta_1}\,|\,X^{(0)}_{\theta_0}=0\,\}.
$
From this definition we get directly the following statements.
%\begin{lemma}\label{gtht0}$\phantom{\R}$
 \begin{enumerate}
  \item If $[X]_m^1\in\g_{\theta_0}$, then $X_m=0$.
    \item The subspace $\g_{\theta_0}$ has the natural Lie algebra structure
$
   \{\,\cdot,\cdot\,\}:\g_{\theta_0}\times\g_{\theta_0}\longrightarrow\g_{\theta_0}
$
 defined by the formula
     $
   \{\,[X]_m^1,[Y]_m^1\,\}=[\,[X,Y]\,]_m^1,\;\;\forall\,[X]_m^1,[Y]_m^1\in\g_{\theta_0},
     $
     where $[X,Y]$ is the usual Lie bracket of vector fields $X$ and $Y$.
   \item The Lie algebra $\g_{\theta_0}$ is naturally identified with corresponding Lie subalgebra of linear operators $T_m M\otimes T_m^*M$.
     \item The Lie algebra $\g_{\theta_0}$ is an isotropy algebra of  the point
     $\theta_0=S(m)$.
  \end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}
We get from proposition~\ref{Atht1} and the first statement of lemma~\ref{gtht0} the following statement.
\begin{proposition}\label{gtht1}
   Let $X$ be a vector field in $M$ defined in a neighborhood of $m$. Then
   $[X]_m^1=(\bar x, \bar X^i, \bar X^i_j)\in\g_{\theta_0}$ if and only if
   \begin{enumerate}
     \item $X_m=(\bar X^i)=0$.
     \item The vector $(\bar X^i_j)$ is a solution of the system of linear algebraic
       equations
\begin{equation}\label{gtht2}
 \begin{aligned}
  &\bar a^j X^i_j-\bar a^i\bar a^j X^0_j=0,\quad \bar g^{kj} X^i_k+\bar g^{ki} X^j_k-2\bar g^{ij}\bar g^{k0} X^0_k=0.
 \end{aligned}
\end{equation}
    \end{enumerate}
\end{proposition}
Taking into account \eqref{GmtrcStrctr1}, we solve system \eqref{gtht2}. As a result, we obtain
\begin{theorem}\label{GsDg03} Let $S$ be the geometric structure generated by the solution $s=(u^1,\ldots,u^{n+2})$ of system \eqref{Gas}, $m=s(x)$, and  $\theta_0=S(m)$. Then:
\begin{enumerate}
\item if $n=1$, then
$
  \g_{\theta_0}=\left\{\;a\begin{pmatrix}
                            1&0\\
                            0&1
                           \end{pmatrix}\;|\; a\in\R \;\right\},
$
%
\item if $n=2$, then
$
  \g_{\theta_0}=\left\{
  \begin{pmatrix}
    \quad a    &  \quad 0 & 0\\
      -b\,u^2(x)   &  \quad a & b\\
    \quad b\,u^1(x) &       -b & a
  \end{pmatrix}
  \bigl|\;a,b\in\R\right\},
$
%
\item if $n=3$, then
$$
  \g_{\theta_0}=\left\{
  \begin{pmatrix}
               a     & \phantom{-}0 & \phantom{-}0 & 0\\
          -b\,u^2(x)-c\,u^3(x) & \phantom{-}a & \phantom{-}b & c\\
\phantom{-}b\,u^1(x)-d\,u^3(x) &           -b & \phantom{-}a & d\\
\phantom{-}c\,u^1(x)+d\,u^2(x) &           -c &           -d & a
  \end{pmatrix}\bigl|\,a,b,c,d\in\R\right\}.
$$
\end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}%===================================================\subsection{Horizontal subspaces}%
Denote by
$
   \tau:TM\longrightarrow M
$
a tangent bundle of $M$.
The following lemma is a direct consequence of definition of the space $\A_{\theta_1}$.
%\begin{lemma}\label{Atht3} The natural projection
$
   \tau_{1,0}\bigl|_{\A_{\theta_1}}:\A_{\theta_1}\longrightarrow T_mM
$
is a surjection.
\end{lemma}
A subspace $H\subset\A_{\theta_1}$ is {\it horizontal} if the natural projection
$
  \tau_{1,0}|_H:H\longrightarrow T_mM
$
is an isomorphism.

Let $H\subset\A_{\theta_1}$ be horizontal, then
$
  \A_{\theta_1}=\g_{\theta_0}\oplus H.
$
Any  two horizontal subspaces $H,\tilde H\subset\A_{\theta_1}$ define a linear map
\begin{equation}\label{LnrMp}
\begin{aligned}
  &\phantom{f_{\tilde H,H}(X_m)=(\tau_{1,0}|_{\tilde H})^{-1}(X_m)} f_{\tilde H,H}\in\g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M,\\
&f_{\tilde H,H}(X_m)=(\tau_{1,0}|_{\tilde H})^{-1}(X_m)-(\tau_{1,0}|_H)^{-1}(X_m),\;\;\forall\, X_m\in T_mM.
\end{aligned}
\end{equation}
On the other hand, let $H\subset\A_{\theta_1}$ be a horizontal subspace and let $f\in\g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M$, then there exists a unique horizontal subspace $\tilde H\subset\A_{\theta_1}$ such that $f=f_{\tilde H,H}$.
%
Indeed, this horizontal subspace is spanned by the 1-jets
$$
(\tau_{1,0}|_H)^{-1}(X_m)+f(X_m),
$$
where $X_m\in T_mM$.
Let's introduce the following natural bilinear map
\begin{gather*}
  [\![\cdot, \cdot ]\!]:\A_{\theta_1}\times\A_{\theta_1}\longrightarrow T_mM,\;\;
 [\![\,[X]_m^1,\,[Y]_m^1\,]\!]= [\,X, Y\,]_m,
\end{gather*}
where the bracket in the right side is the usual bracket of vector fields.
Every horizontal subspace $H\subset\A_{\theta_1}$ generates the 2-form
\begin{gather*}
  \omega_H\in T_mM\otimes\bigl(T_m^*M\wedge T_m^*M\bigr), \\
  \omega_H(X_m,Y_m)=[\![\,(\tau_{1,0}|_H)^{-1}(X_m),\, (\tau_{1,0}|_H)^{-1}(Y_m)\,]\!],\quad\forall\,X_m,Y_m\in T_mM.
\end{gather*}%=====================================================\subsection{The structural invariant}%
The group $\g_{\theta_0}\subset T_mM\otimes T_m^*M$ generates the Spencer $\delta$-complex, see \cite{GllmnStrnbrg},
\begin{equation}\label{Spncr}
  0\to(\g_{\theta_0})^{(1)}\hookrightarrow \g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M\xrightarrow{\partial} T_mM\otimes\bigl(\wedge^2 T_m^*M\bigr)\to 0,
\end{equation}
where  $\g_{\theta_0}^{(1)}$ is the first prolongation of the algebra $\g_{\theta_0}$ defined by the formula
$$
  \g_{\theta_0}^{(1)}=\bigl(\g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M\bigr)\cap\Bigl( T_mM\otimes\bigl(T_m^*M\odot T_m^*M\bigr)\Bigr),
$$
the morphism $\hookrightarrow$ means the inclusion map, and the differential $\partial$ is defined by the formula
 $$
 \partial(f)(X_m,Y_m)= f(X_m)Y_m-f(Y_m)X_m,\quad\forall\,X_m,Y_m\in T_mM.
 $$%\begin{theorem} The cohomology class
$
  \omega_H+\partial\bigl(\g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M\bigr)
$
is independent of choice of horizontal subspace $H\subset\A_{\theta_1}$.
\end{theorem}\begin{proof}
Let $H,\tilde H$ be horizontal subspaces of $\A_{\theta_1}$ and let $X_m, Y_m\in T_mM$. Then we can put
$
  [X]_m^1=(\tau|_H)^{-1}(X_m),\quad[Y]_m^1=(\tau|_H)^{-1}(Y_m).
$
From \eqref{LnrMp}, we get
$$
(\tau|_{\tilde H})^{-1}(X_m)=[X]_m^1+f_{\tilde H,H}(X_m),\;\;
(\tau|_{\tilde H})^{-1}(Y_m)=[Y]_m^1+f_{\tilde H,H}(Y_m).
$$
Hence,
\begin{multline*}
  \omega_H(X_m,Y_m)-\omega_{\tilde H}(X_m,Y_m) =[\![[X]_m^1,[Y]_m^1]\!]-[\![[X]_m^1+f_{\tilde H,H}(X_m),[Y]_m^1+f_{\tilde H,H}(Y_m)]\!]=\\
  =[\![[Y]_m^1,f_{\tilde H,H}(X_m)]\!]-[\![[X]_m^1,f_{\tilde H,H}(Y_m)]\!]
=f_{\tilde H,H}(X_m)Y_m-f_{\tilde H,H}(Y_m)X_m.
\end{multline*}
\end{proof}
The cohomology class $\omega_H+\partial\bigl(\g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M\bigr)$ is defined by the 1-jet $\theta_1=[S]_m^1\in L_S^{(1)}$. Thus we construct the natural function on $L_S^{(1)}$ with values in Spencer cohomologies,
\begin{equation}\label{ChmlgInvrnt}
  \omega:\theta_1\longmapsto \omega_H+\partial\bigl(\g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M\bigr), \;\; \theta_1\in L_S^{(1)}.
\end{equation}
Taking into account that the projection
$\lambda_{1,0}\bigl|_{L_S^{(1)}}:L_S^{(1)}\to M$ is a diffeomorphism, we can consider this function as a function on $M$,
This function is a first order differential invariant of the geometric structure $S$.

%====================================================\subsection{The tensor invariant}%
The natural conformal metric $g$, see \eqref{CnfrmlMtrc}, on $M$ generates in natural way the
conformal metric $\widehat g$ on the bundle $TM\otimes\bigl(\wedge^2T^*M\bigr)$.

Let $\bigl(\partial(\g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M)\bigr)^{\perp}$ be the orthogonal complement to subspace $\partial\bigl(\g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M\bigr)\subset T_mM\otimes\bigl(\wedge^2T_m^*M\bigr)$ with respect to the metric $\widehat g$.
%\begin{remark}\label{OrthCmplmnt}
 \begin{enumerate}
  \item If $n=1$, then $\bigl(\partial(\g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M)\bigr)^{\perp}=\{0\}$.
  \item If $n=2,3$, then $\bigl(\partial(\g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M)\bigr)^{\perp}\neq \{0\}$.
 \end{enumerate}
\end{remark}
The following statement can be proved by direct calculations.
%\begin{theorem} Let $\theta_0=S(m)$ and $m\in M$. Then the following natural direct sum decomposition holds
$$
  T_mM\otimes\bigl(\wedge^2 T_m^*M\bigr)
=\bigl(\partial(\g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M)\bigr)^{\perp}
\oplus\partial\bigl(\g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M\bigr),\;\;\forall\, m\in M.
$$
\end{theorem}
This decomposition imply the following statements.
%\begin{theorem} Let $m\in M$, $\theta_0=S(m)$, and $\theta_1=[S]_m^1$. Then the following statements valid.
 \begin{enumerate}
   \item There exists a unique 2-form
$\T_m\in \omega_H+\partial\bigl(\g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M\bigr)$ such that $$
   \T_m\in\bigl(\partial(\g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M)\bigr)^{\perp}.
$$
    \item The differential vector-valued 2-form on $M$
$
  \T:m\longmapsto \T_m
$
is a first order differential invariant of the structure $S$.
 \end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}
We get the following explicit expressions of $\T$ by direct calculations in coordinates.
\begin{enumerate}
\item If $n=1$, then
\begin{equation}\label{TrsnFrm1}
  \T=0.
\end{equation}
\item If $n=2$, then
\begin{multline}\label{TrsnFrm2}
\T=\frac12(u^1_1 - u^2_2)\partial_{x^1}\otimes dx^0\wedge dx^1
+\frac12 (u^1_2 + u^2_1)\partial_{x^1}\otimes dx^0\wedge dx^2 \\
+ \frac12 (u^1_2 + u^2_1)\partial_{x^2}\otimes dx^0\wedge dx^1
- \frac12(u^1_1 - u^2_2)\partial_{x^2}\otimes dx^0\wedge dx^2.
\end{multline}
\item If $n=3$, then
\begin{multline}\label{TrsnFrm3}
  \T=\frac13(-u^3_3-u^2_2+2u^1_1)\,\partial_{x^1}\otimes dx^0\wedge dx^1
     +\frac12(u^2_1+u^1_2)\,\partial_{x^1}\otimes dx^0\wedge dx^2\\
     +\frac12(u^3_1+u^1_3)\,\partial_{x^1}\otimes dx^0\wedge dx^3\\
     +\frac12(u^2_1+u^1_2)\,\partial_{x^2}\otimes dx^0\wedge dx^1
     +\frac13(-u^3_3+2u^2_2-u^1_1)\,\partial_{x^2}\otimes dx^0\wedge dx^2\\
     +\frac12(u^3_2+u^2_3)\,\partial_{x^2}\otimes dx^0\wedge dx^3\\
     +\frac12(u^3_1+u^1_3)\,\partial_{x^3}\otimes dx^0\wedge dx^1
     +\frac12(u^3_2+u^2_3)\,\partial_{x^3}\otimes dx^0\wedge dx^2\\
 +\frac13(2u^3_3-u^2_2-u^1_1)\,\partial_{x^3}\otimes dx^0\wedge dx^3.
\end{multline}
\end{enumerate}%=====================================================\subsection{Natural linear connections on solutions}%
We find now a first order differential invariant of the structure $S$, which is a linear connection on $M$.

\begin{lemma}\label{Spncr1} Let $m\in M$ and $\theta_0=S(m)$. Then
 \begin{enumerate}
  \item $\g_{\theta_0}^{(1)}=\{0\}$.
  \item The differential $\partial$ of complex \eqref{Spncr} is injective.
 \end{enumerate}
\end{lemma}\begin{proof} The first statement is proved by direct calculations.
The second one follows from the inclusions
$
   \ker\partial\subset\g_{\theta_0}^{(1)}\subset\g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M
$
and the first statement.
\end{proof}\begin{theorem}\label{UnqnssH} Let $m\in M$, $\theta_0=S(m)$, and $\theta_1=[S]_m^1$. Then
 \begin{enumerate}
  \item There exists a unique horizontal subspace $H_m\in\A_{\theta_1}$ such that
$
   \omega_{H_m}=\T_m.
$
  \item The subspace $H_m$ is naturally defined.
 \end{enumerate}
\end{theorem}\begin{proof}
At first we prove that the required subspace $H_m$ exists. Let $H$ be a horizontal subspace of $\A_{\theta_1}$. Then
$
   \T_m-\omega_H\in\partial\bigl(\g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M\bigr).
$
%
It follows from statement (2) of lemma~\ref{Spncr1} that there exists a unique $f\in \g_{\theta_0}\otimes T_m^*M$ such that
$
   \partial(f)=\T_m-\omega_H.
$
%

Let $H_m$ be the horizontal subspace of $\A_{\theta_1}$ spanned by 1-jets
$$
f(X_m)-(\tau_{1,0}\bigl|_H)^{-1}(X_m),\quad X_m\in T_mM.
$$
Then we obtain
\begin{multline*}
  \omega_{H_m}(X_m,Y_m) %\\
=[\![\,f(X_m)-(\tau_{1,0}|_H)^{-1}(X_m),    f(Y_m)-(\tau_{1,0}|_H)^{-1}(Y_m)\,]\!]\\
=\partial(f)(X_m, Y_m)+\omega_H(X_m,Y_m)
=\T_m(X_m, Y_m)\;\;\forall\, X_m,Y_m\in T_mM.
\end{multline*}

Let us prove that the required subspace $H_m$ is unique. Suppose that $H_m$ and  $\tilde H_m$ are different horizontal subspaces of $\A_{\theta_1}$ such that
$\omega_{H_m}=\T_m=\omega_{\tilde H_m}$. Then
\begin{multline*}
    0=\omega_H(X_m,Y_m)-\omega_{\tilde H}(X_m,Y_m)=f_{\tilde H,H}(X_m)Y_m-f_{\tilde H,H}(Y_m)X_m,\;\;\forall\, X_m,Y_m\in T_mM.
\end{multline*}
Hence $f_{\tilde H,H}\in\g_{\theta_0}^{(1)}$. From lemma~\ref{Spncr1}, we get that $f_{\tilde H,H}=0$. This means that $H_m=\tilde H_m$.

The second statement now is obvious.
\end{proof}%\begin{theorem}  There exists a natural linear connection on $M$ such that  its torsion tensor is the 2-form $\T$.
\end{theorem}\begin{proof} Consider the natural field of horizontal subspaces on $M$
$$
  m\longmapsto H_m\subset\A_{\theta_1}\subset J_m^1\tau,\;\; m\in M.
$$
This field generates the natural linear connection on $M$
\begin{equation}\label{NtrlLnrCnnctn}
\LnCn : TM\longrightarrow J^1\tau,\quad
    \LnCn : X_m\mapsto (\tau_{1,0}|_{H_m})^{-1}(X_m)\in H_m
\end{equation}
(a suitable definition of linear connection see, for example, in \cite{Pl}).
From Theorem~\ref{UnqnssH} we see that the torsion tensor of this connection is $\T$.
\end{proof}%--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsubsection{Coordinates} Let $s=(v,\rho,p)$ be a solution of  equations of adiabatic gas motion \eqref{Gas} for $n=1$ and let $\LnCn^i_{jk}$ be components of the linear connection on $M$ defined by \eqref{NtrlLnrCnnctn}. Then one can obtain by direct calculations that
\begin{equation}\label{NtrlLnrCnnctn1}
 \begin{aligned}
  &\LnCn^0_{00}=\frac{v\alpha_x-v_x\alpha+\alpha_t}{\alpha},\quad
  \LnCn^0_{01}=\LnCn^0_{10}=0,\quad
  \LnCn^0_{1,1}=0, \\
  &\LnCn^1_{00}=\frac{v\alpha_t-v_t\alpha}{\alpha},\quad
  \LnCn^1_{01}=\LnCn^1_{10}=\frac{v\alpha_x-v_x\alpha}{\alpha},\quad
  \LnCn^1_{1,1}=-\frac{\alpha_x}{\alpha},
 \end{aligned}
\end{equation}
where $\alpha=\sqrt{A(\rho,p)/\rho}$; $\alpha_t$, $\alpha_x$ and $v_t$, $v_x$ are derivatives of  functions $\alpha$ and $v$ with respect to variables $t$ and $x$ respectively.
A curvature tensor $\Rm_S$ of this linear connection is defined by the formula
\begin{multline}\label{Curv3Wb}
  \Rm_S=\frac{1}{\alpha^2}(\,- \alpha\alpha_{tx} - v\alpha\alpha_{xx} + v_{xx}\alpha^2
   + \alpha_t\alpha_x + v\alpha_x^2 - v_x\alpha\alpha_x\,)\,dt\wedge dx.
\end{multline}
The tensor $\Rm_S$ is a differential invariant  of second order of the geometric structure $S$ on solution $s$.

%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

%
We represent here some explicit solutions of system \eqref{Gas} possessing the linear connection with zero curvature tensor (for the case $n=1$) or zero torsion tensor (for the case $n=2,3$).
%===================================================\subsection{One dimensional solutions}%
We get from \eqref{Curv3Wb} that a solution $s=(v,\rho,p)$ of system \eqref{Gas}, $n=1$,  possess the linear connection with zero curvature tensor if and only if
$
  - \alpha\alpha_{tx} - v\alpha\alpha_{xx} + v_{xx}\alpha^2
   + \alpha_t\alpha_x + v\alpha_x^2 - v_x\alpha\alpha_x =0.
$
The last equation is rather complicated. It transforms to the equation
$
  v_{xx}=0
$
in the case
$
  A(\rho,p)=\rho.
$
The following solutions of system \eqref{Gas}, $n=1$, $A(\rho, p)=\rho$, have the linear connection with zero curvature tensor:
\begin{equation}\label{Sol1}
\begin{aligned}
  v(t,x)&=\frac{x+c_3}{t+c_1}-\frac{t+c_1}{2}-c_2\,,\\
\rho(t,x)&=c_2(t+c_1)^{c_2^2-1}\exp\left[\,\frac{c_2(x+c_3)}{t+c_1}+\frac{c_2}{2}t +c_4\,\right]\,,\\
  p(t,x)&=\left(\,\frac{c_2}{t+c_1}+1\right)(t+c_1)^{c_2^2}\exp\left[\,\frac{c_2(x+c_3)}{t+c_1}+\frac{c_2}{2}t +c_4\,\right]\,,
 \end{aligned}
\end{equation}
where $c_1$, $c_2$, $c_3$, and $c_4$ are constants.

%===================================================\subsection{Two dimensional solutions}%
It follows from \eqref{TrsnFrm2} that a solution $s=(v^1,v^2,\rho,p)$ of system \eqref{Gas}, $n=2$,  possess the linear connection with zero torsion tensor if and only if
$
  v^1_x=v^2_y,\quad v^1_y=-v^2_x.
$
Consider a polytropic adiabatic gas flow, that is a gas flow describing by equations \eqref{Gas} with
$
   A(\rho,p)=\gamma p,
$
where $\gamma$ is a positive constant.

The following solutions (see \cite{YmYm}) of system \eqref{Gas}, $n=2$, $A(\rho, p)=\gamma p$, possess the linear connection with zero torsion tensor
%\begin{equation}\label{Sol2}
 \begin{aligned}
 &v^1(t,x,y)=\frac{t+k_1}{(t+k_1)^2+k_2^2}\,x+\frac{k_2}{(t+k_1)^2+k_2^2}\,y+c(t)\,,\;k_2\neq 0\,,\\
 &v^2(t,x,y)=\frac{k_2}{(t+k_1)^2+k_2^2}\,x+\frac{t+k_1}{(t+k_1)^2-k_2^2}\,y+d(t)\,,\\
 &\rho(t,x,y)=\frac{e^{-2k_3+k_4}}{(t+k_1)^2+k_2^2}\,\exp f,\quad p(t,x,y)=\frac{e^{-2\gamma k_3+k_4}}{\bigl((t+k_1)^2+k_2^2\bigr)^{\gamma}}\,\exp f\,,
 \end{aligned}
\end{equation}
where
\begin{multline*}
 f=\frac{e^{-k_3}}{\bigl((t+k_1)^2+k_2^2\bigr)^{1/2}}\bigl(\,x(\cos\beta-\sin\beta)+y(\cos\beta+\sin\beta)\,\bigr)\\
 -\int\frac{e^{-k_3}}{\bigl((t+k_1)^2+k_2^2\bigr)^{1/2}}
 \bigl(\,c(t)(\cos\beta-\sin\beta)+d(t)(\cos\beta+\sin\beta)\,\bigr)dt\,,
\end{multline*}$$
 \beta={\rm arctg}\Bigl(\frac{t+k_1}{k_2}\Bigr)+k_5\,,
$$$$
  c(t)=\bigl((e^{(1-2\gamma)k_3}\Gamma_c+k_6)\cos\beta-(e^{(1-2\gamma)k_3}\Gamma_d+k_7)\sin\beta\bigr)
  \bigl((t+k_1)^2+k_2^2\bigr)^{\frac12},
$$$$
  d(t)=\bigl((e^{(1-2\gamma)k_3}\Gamma_c+k_6)\sin\beta+(e^{(1-2\gamma)k_3}\Gamma_d+k_7)\cos\beta\bigr)
  \bigl((t+k_1)^2+k_2^2\bigr)^{\frac12},
$$\begin{multline*}
 \Gamma_c=\frac{1}{\delta^2+1}\int\frac{1}{\bigl((t+k_1)^2+k_2^2\bigr)^{\gamma+1}}
 \bigl((\delta^2-2\delta-1)(t+k_1)^2\\
 +2k_1(-\delta^2-2\delta+1)(t+k_1)+k_1^2(-\delta^2+2\delta+1)\bigr)dt\,,
\end{multline*}\begin{multline*}
 \Gamma_d=\frac{1}{\delta^2+1}\int\frac{1}{\bigl((t+k_1)^2+k_2^2\bigr)^{\gamma+1}}
 \bigl((\delta^2+2\delta-1)(t+k_1)^2\\
 +2k_1(\delta^2-2\delta-1)(t+k_1)+k_1^2(-\delta^2-2\delta+1)\bigr)dt\,,
\end{multline*}$\delta={\rm tg}(k_5)$, and $k_1$, $\ldots\,$, $k_7$ are arbitrary constants.

%===================================================\subsection{Three dimensional solutions}%
From \eqref{TrsnFrm3} we get that the condition $\T=0$ is equivalent to the following ones:
$$
      v^2_x+v^1_y=0,\quad v^3_x+v^1_z=0,\quad v^3_y+v^2_z=0,\quad v^1_x-v^2_y=0,\quad  v^2_y-v^3_z=0.
$$
Below we represent families of some solutions (see \cite{Yum3}) of system \eqref{Gas}, $n=3$, $A(\rho, p)=\gamma p$, possessing the linear connection with zero torsion tensor.

%------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsubsection{Solutions with zero torsion, $\gamma\neq 4/3$ and $\gamma\neq 1$}%\begin{equation}\label{Sol31}
\begin{aligned}
   &v^1(t,x,y,z)=\frac{x+k_3}{t+k_1}-\frac{e^{(2-3\gamma)k_2}}{4-3\gamma}(t+k_1)^{2-3\gamma}|t+k_1|,\\
   &v^2(t,x,y,z)=\frac{y+k_4}{t+k_1}-\frac{e^{(2-3\gamma)k_2}}{4-3\gamma}(t+k_1)^{2-3\gamma}|t+k_1|,\\
   &v^3(t,x,y,z)=\frac{z+k_5}{t+k_1}-\frac{e^{(2-3\gamma)k_2}}{4-3\gamma}(t+k_1)^{2-3\gamma}|t+k_1|,\\
   &\rho(t,x,y,z)=\frac{e^{-3k_2+k_6}}{|t+k_1|^3}\exp f,\quad p(t,x,y,z)=\frac{e^{-3k_2\gamma+k_6}}{|t+k_1|(t+k_1)^{3\gamma-1}}\exp f,
\end{aligned}
\end{equation}
where
\begin{multline*}
  f=I^1+I^2+I^3=e^{-k_2}\,\frac{x+y+z+k_3+k_4+k_5}{|t+k_1|}
+e^{(1-3\gamma)k_2}\,\frac{3(t+k_1)^{3-3\gamma}}{(3-3\gamma)(4-3\gamma)}
\end{multline*}
and $k_1, \ldots, k_6$ are arbitrary constants.

%-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------\subsubsection{The case $\gamma=4/3$}%\begin{equation}\label{Sol32}
\begin{aligned}
   &v^1(t,x,y,z)=\frac{x+k_3}{t+k_1}-e^{-2k_2}\,\frac{\ln|t+k_1|}{t+k_1},\\
   &v^2(t,x,y,z)=\frac{y+k_4}{t+k_1}-e^{-2k_2}\,\frac{\ln|t+k_1|}{t+k_1},\\
   &v^3(t,x,y,z)=\frac{z+k_5}{t+k_1}-e^{-2k_2}\,\frac{\ln|t+k_1|}{t+k_1},\\
   &\rho(t,x,y,z)=\frac{e^{-3k_2}}{|t+k_1|^3}\exp f,\quad p(t,x,y,z)=\frac{e^{-4k_2}}{(t+k_1)^4}\exp f,
\end{aligned}
\end{equation}
where
$$
 f=e^{-k_2}\,\frac{x+y+z+k_3+k_4+k_5}{|t+k_1|}
   -3e^{-3k_2}\,\frac{\ln|t+k_1|+1}{|t+k_1|}+k_6
$$
and $k_1,\ldots, k_6$ are arbitrary constants.

%-----------------------------------------------------\subsubsection{The case $\gamma=1$}%\begin{equation}\label{Sol33}
\begin{aligned}
   &v^1(t,x,y,z)=\frac{x+k_3}{t+k_1}-e^{-k_2}\,\frac{t}{|t+k_1|},\quad v^2(t,x,y,z)=\frac{y+k_4}{t+k_1}-e^{-k_2}\,\frac{t}{|t+k_1|},\\
   &v^3(t,x,y,z)=\frac{z+k_5}{t+k_1}-e^{-k_2}\,\frac{t}{|t+k_1|},\\
   &\rho(t,x,y,z)=\frac{e^{-3k_2}}{|t+k_1|^3}\exp f,\quad p(t,x,y,z)=\frac{e^{-3k_2}}{|t+k_1|^3}\exp f,
\end{aligned}
\end{equation}
where
$$
 f=e^{-k_2}\,\frac{x+y+z+k_3+k_4+k_5}{|t+k_1|}
   +3e^{-2k_2}\,\bigl(\ln|t+k_1|+\frac{k_1}{t+k_1}\bigr)+k_6
$$
and $k_1,\ldots, k_6$ are arbitrary constants.
